channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-16524] Procedure v2 - Compute WALs cleanup on wal modification and not on every sync
item.description:
Fix performance regression introduced by HBASE-16094.

Instead of scanning all the wals every time, we can rely on the insert/update/delete events we have.
and since we want to delete the wals in order we can keep track of what is "holding" that wal, and take a hit on scanning all the trackers only when we remove the first log in the queue.
e.g.
WAL-1 [1, 2]
WAL-2 [1] -> "[2] is holding WAL-1"
WAL-3 [2] -> "WAL 1 can be removed, recompute what is holding WAL-2"
item.summary: Procedure v2 - Compute WALs cleanup on wal modification and not on every sync

status.description: A patch for this issue has been uploaded to JIRA by a contributor.

comments.comment:
let's try to keep 001 as last resource.

we can try to think about a couple of other stuff first
like find where is the bottleneck of the current removeInactiveLogs() and see if we can improve that.
and also I'd will be nice if we can predict exactly when is the best time to call removeInactiveLogs() instead of just guessing based on time. we should have all the information we need to spot the pattern to know when the log should be removed.

-1 overall

This message was automatically generated.

Attaching flame graph form a run of ./bin/hbase org.apache.hadoop.hbase.procedure2.store.wal.ProcedureWALPerformanceEvaluation -procs 500000 (captured 15sec).
As expected, bottleneck is subtraction of two bitmaps.

The lowest hanging fruit here is to not call removeInactiveLogs() on every sync.
Also, instead of waiting for a predetermined (and randomly) chosen time, it'll be better to call the cleaner once every wal roll. Only the written wals (not the active one) are used to decided the obsolete ones, therefore, calling removeInactiveLogs() repeatedly until the active log is rolled won't mark any new logs for removal.

before adding conditions to reduce the number of times we call removeInactiveLogs(), let's try to improve the algorithm.

executing every roll does not provide the result we want.
e.g. WAL-1: [1, 2], Current: [] as soon we update [1, 2] we can remove WAL-1
e.g. WAL-1: [1], WAL-2: [2], Current [] as soon we update [1, 2] we can remove WAL-1 and WAL-2

Thinking about it, that should be easy to do.
In our current logic, we basically do this:
1. make a copy of current global tracker, say T.
2. Iterate over log files:

  • keep the file if contain an update to proc P which is not marked deleted in T.
  • Delete P from T so we don't hold another older log file because of it.

The new steps would be:
1. make a copy of current global tracker, say T.
2. Mark all recently updated procs as deleted in T (so we don't hold logs because of these procs)
3. (step 2 above in old logic) Iterate over log files:

  • keep the file if contain an update to proc P which is not marked deleted in T.
  • Delete P from T so we don't hold another older log file because of it.
    Sounds good?

Instead of scanning all the wals every time, we can rely on the insert/update/delete events we have.
and since we want to delete the wals in order we can keep track of what is "holding" that wal, and take a hit on scanning all the trackers only when we remove the first log in the queue.

e.g.
WAL-1 [1, 2]
WAL-2 [1] -> "[2] is holding WAL-1"
WAL-3 [2] -> "WAL 1 can be removed, recompute what is holding WAL-2"

+1 overall
